title: How to Send Documents Securely on PC or Mac

steps.title: Open the document in Microsoft Word.
steps.content: Open the document in Microsoft Word. The quickest way to do this is to double-click its file name.

steps.title: Click the File menu.
steps.content: Click the File menu. It’s at the top-left corner of the window (or in the menu bar on a Mac). [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Info.
steps.content: Click Info .

steps.title: Click Protect Document.
steps.content: Click Protect Document .

steps.title: Click Encrypt with Password.
steps.content: Click Encrypt with Password .

steps.title: Create and confirm the document password.
steps.content: Create and confirm the document password. Follow the on-screen instructions to type and confirm the password that will protect your document.

steps.title: Save the file.
steps.content: Save the file. Click the File menu and select Save to save the new version of your document.

steps.title: Share the document with others.
steps.content: Share the document with others. Now that the file is password protected, you can send it in a variety of ways: Attach the document to an email message in Gmail , Outlook, or Mac Mail. Add the file to a cloud drive like Google Drive , iCloud Drive, or Dropbox.

steps.title: Open Outlook on your PC or Mac.
steps.content: Open Outlook on your PC or Mac. It’s usually in All Apps area of the Start menu in Windows, and in the Applications folder in macOS.

steps.title: Click New Email.
steps.content: Click New Email . It’s the envelope icon at the top-left corner of the window.

steps.title: Click the File menu.
steps.content: Click the File menu. It’s near the top-left corner of the screen. If you’re using Outlook 2010, click the Options menu, then select More Options .

steps.title: Click Properties.
steps.content: Click Properties . If you’re using Outlook 2010, skip to the next step.

steps.title: Click Security settings.
steps.content: Click Security settings .

steps.title: Check the box next to “Encrypt message contents and attachments.”
steps.content: Check the box next to “Encrypt message contents and attachments.”

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . This message will now be encrypted.

steps.title: Click Close.
steps.content: Click Close . Now that the encryption settings are set, you can create the message.

steps.title: Enter a recipient, subject, and message.
steps.content: Enter a recipient, subject, and message.

steps.title: Click Attach file.
steps.content: Click Attach file . It’s the paperclip icon at the top of the new message. This opens your computer’s file browser. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Select the attachment and click Open.
steps.content: Select the attachment and click Open . This attaches the file to the message.

steps.title: Click Send.
steps.content: Click Send . The message will now be delivered to the recipient.

steps.title: Navigate to the file you want to encrypt.
steps.content: Navigate to the file you want to encrypt. An easy way to do this is to press ⊞ Win + E to open the File Explorer, then double-click the folder that contains the file.

steps.title: Right-click the file or folder.
steps.content: Right-click the file or folder. A context menu will expand.

steps.title: Click Properties.
steps.content: Click Properties . It’s the last option in the menu.

steps.title: Click Advanced.
steps.content: Click Advanced . It’s near the bottom-right corner of the window.

steps.title: Check the box next to “Encrypt contents to secure data.”
steps.content: Check the box next to “Encrypt contents to secure data.” It’s the last option on the window.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . If you selected a folder, a confirmation message will appear.

steps.title: Select Apply changes to this folder, subfolders and files.
steps.content: Select Apply changes to this folder, subfolders and files .

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . The selected file or folder is now encrypted. To access the file or folder, you’ll have to use your Windows login credentials.

steps.title: Send the encrypted document.
steps.content: Send the encrypted document. If you encrypted only one file, you can attach it to an email message. You can't compress the folder and then attach it to an email. If you encrypted a folder, upload it to a cloud drive like Google Drive , iCloud Drive, or Dropbox. Once uploaded, use the drive’s tools to share the files as you wish.

steps.title: Add the file you want to encrypt to a folder.
steps.content: Add the file you want to encrypt to a folder. If you’re not sure how to do this, see Make a New Folder on a Computer .

steps.title: Click the Go menu.
steps.content: Click the Go menu. It’s at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Utilities.
steps.content: Click Utilities . It’s near the bottom of the menu. A new Finder window will open.

steps.title: Double-click Disk Utility.
steps.content: Double-click Disk Utility . This opens the Disk Utility app.

steps.title: Click the File menu.
steps.content: Click the File menu. It’s in the menu bar at the top-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Hover the mouse over New.
steps.content: Hover the mouse over New . Another menu will expand.

steps.title: Click Image from folder.
steps.content: Click Image from folder .

steps.title: Select the folder you want to encrypt and click Choose.
steps.content: Select the folder you want to encrypt and click Choose .

steps.title: Select 128-bit or 256-bit from the “encryption” drop-down menu.
steps.content: Select 128-bit or 256-bit from the “encryption” drop-down menu.

steps.title: Create a password.
steps.content: Create a password. Enter a new password for the folder into the “Password” box, then again in the “Verify” box.

steps.title: Click Choose.
steps.content: Click Choose .

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save .

steps.title: Click Done.
steps.content: Click Done . The files in the folder are now encrypted. Now you can upload the folder to a cloud drive like Google Drive , iCloud Drive, or Dropbox. Once uploaded, use the drive’s tools to share the files as you wish.
